entry.title: Billing Plan Template in Service Order Process
entry.content:
You can use an ad hoc billing plan on service order item to define the dates on which billing is to occur and the value that is to be billed. With this you can bill on specific dates and not just when the service order item is completed. For each billing date, you can enter a billing request line (BRL) manually. 

In this blog I am going to explain how you can use a billing plan template so that the system creates such billing request lines and manual creation is no longer necessary.

First, configurations in Customizing must be completed as prerequisites for the automatic creation of billing request lines in an ad hoc billing plan for a service order item. 

 

Create Billing Plan Template

You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Service -> Transactions -> Basic Settings -> Billing Plan -> Create Billing Plan Templates.

After you click on Create button, a new entry screen is displayed. You enter a template ID, a description and a long description. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 1.) 

Figure 1: Define details of a new billing plan template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You click on node Billing Plan Template Lines on the left panel and in the opened screen on the right panel you click on New Entries. You maintain line numbers, descriptions, billing value percentage and a date rule. You can also maintain a billing block reason. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 2.) 

 Figure 2: Define billing plan template lines (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You click on node Sales Areas of Billing Plan Template on the left panel and in the opened screen on the right panel you click on New Entries. You maintain a sales organization, a distribution channel and a division for that the billing plan template shall be determined. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 3.) 

 Figure 3: Maintain sales are of a billing plan template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

You click on node Item Categories of Billing Plan Template on the left panel and in the opened screen on the right panel you click on New Entries. You choose an item category for that your billing plan template shall be determined. You save it. (See screenshot in Figure 4.)

Figure 4: Choose item categories (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

Activate Billing Plan Template Determination

You check which billing plan type is assigned to your service order item categories in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Service -> Transactions -> Basic Settings -> Billing Plan -> Assign Billing Plan Type to Item Category. (See screenshot in Figure 5.)

Figure 5: Billing plan type assignment (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Service -> Transactions -> Basic Settings -> Billing Plan -> Define Billing Plan Types

You select the billing plan type that you have assigned to service order item categories and open the details.

You flag the checkbox of Determine Billing Plan Template. (See screenshot in Figure 6.) and save it.

Figure 6: Activate determination of billing plan template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

Use of Billing Plan Template in a Service Quotation

You create a service quotation for customer 17100001 in sales area 1710 as sales organization, 10 as distribution channel, 00 as division. You add an item for service product SRV_01 and quantity 1, and choose the item category SrvItm (Enabl Ad Hoc) (SBQS). (See screenshot in Figure 7.)

Figure 7: Service Quotation Item List (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You open the details of item 10 and add the assignment block Billing to the overview page. You maintain the previously created billing plan template in the corresponding field. (See screenshot in Figure 8.)

Figure 8: Assignment block Billing (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Or you open the value help, search with the sales area and select the line for determined billing plan template. (See screenshot in Figure 9.)

Figure 9: Value Help for Billing Plan Template (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You click on Apply and save the service quotation. You send this quotation to the customer (service quotation is released). You click on button Accept. With this, a service order is created as follow-up and the service quotation is completed. You use the link on service order in the assignment block Transaction History. The service order is opened and you check that an item is created.

You open the details of this service order item and click on Billing Plan.

You check that two billing request lines are created accordingly to the settings of the billing plan template that you have maintained already in the service quotation item:

  • Billing dates are calculated accordingly to the maintained date rules of the billing plan template lines.
  • Billing values are calculated accordingly to the maintained percentages of the billing plan template lines.
  • Descriptions are copied as maintained on the billing plan template lines.
  • Billing blocks are copied as maintained on the billing plan template lines, in this example no billing block.

(See screenshot in Figure 10.)

Figure 10: Automatically created billing request lines (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

What did the system?

  • The billing plan template is copied directly from the service quotation item to the service order item
  • The copied billing plan template is immediately applied to the service order item.

As a result:

  • Billing request lines for an ad hoc billing plan are created automatically.
  • The check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value succeeds and no error message is displayed. (Message CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604 is not raised.)

The key benefit is that no additional manual changes are needed on the service order item to achieve a valid ad hoc billing plan.

 

Use of Billing Plan Template in a Service Order

You create a service order without predecessor service quotation. So, you enter customer 17100001 for sales area 1710 as sales organization, 10 as distribution channel, 00 as division.

You add an item for service product SRV_01 and quantity 1, and choose the item category Service (Ad Hoc Bil) (SBOS).

You check that the check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value doesn't result in an error message. (Message CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604 is not raised.) 

(See screenshot in Figure 11.)

Figure 11: Service Order Item List  (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You open the details of service order item 10 and click on Billing Plan.

You check that two billing request lines are created accordingly to the data of the determined billing plan template.

  • Billing dates are calculated accordingly to the maintained date rules.
  • Billing values are calculated accordingly to the maintained percentages.
  • Descriptions are copied
  • As no billing block was used in the billing plan template, no billing block is copied.

(See screenshot in Figure 12.) 

Figure 12: Service Order Item Billing Plan (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

 

What did the system?

  • The determined billing plan template is immediately applied to the service order item.

As a result:

  • Billing request lines for an ad hoc billing plan are created automatically.
  • The check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value succeeds, and no error message is displayed. (Message CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604 is not raised.)

The key benefit is that no additional manual changes are needed on the service order item to achieve a valid ad hoc billing plan.

 

Notes

If you create a service order item and the system would determine more than one billing plan template, no billing plan template would be applied. The check Sum of BRL billing values must be exactly the same as the item net value would fail and an error message would be displayed (CRMS4_ORDER_MISC/604).

 

Conclusion

Hopefully after reading this blog post, you will have more in-depth knowledge about the usage of billing plan templates in service order process.

Please don‚Äôt hesitate to raise your questions in Q&A forum of SAP Community or leave your comments below!

For more details, please visit the full product assistance documentation in the SAP Help Portal:

  • Billing Plan Templates for Ad Hoc Billing Plans in Service Orders | SAP Help Portal
  • Billing Plan Templates in Service Quotations | SAP Help Portal
  • Ad Hoc Billing for Service Orders | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q4-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
Happy New Year and cheers to a sustainable year ahead! As we kick off 2026, I‚Äôm back with my quarterly blog series about the latest innovations and highlights in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. In this edition, I‚Äôm covering:

  • Multi-Impact Categories
  • Streamlined Energy Management
  • Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections
  • Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide
  • BASF Coatings‚Äô Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Additional Information

 

Multi-Impact Categories

One of the most significant innovations this quarter is the introduction of multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, moving the product beyond carbon. Built on the same ERP-driven data foundation, governance model, and auditability, the latest updates extend the calculation engine to cover additional environmental impact categories. This lets you monitor a broader spectrum of environmental pressures without changing the way you integrate data or run calculations.

Think of multi-impact categories as different lenses on how your operations affect the Earth system. Aligned with planetary boundaries, they translate the data you already have into indicators for climate and other dimensions like land use, biosphere integrity, and biogeochemical flows. That means you can see where improvements in one area risk shifting burdens elsewhere ‚Äì and manage those trade-offs with real numbers.

This matters for reporting because one consistent dataset can now serve multiple frameworks (e.g., CSRD, SBTi FLAG), reducing parallel tools and strengthening credibility with synchronized, audit-ready figures for sustainability, finance, and controlling. But this also matters for decision-making because placing multi‚Äëimpact indicators alongside financial and operational KPIs brings sustainability into core business steering. A richer picture of environmental pressure helps identify where reductions also improve efficiency, resilience, and brand value ‚Äì and where hidden risks accumulate. This supports a shift from compliance‚Äëdriven reporting to performance‚Äëdriven management, where sustainability becomes a source of competitiveness and innovation.

Importantly, nothing changes in how you run the system. You still reuse ERP data, automate activity data collection, map to imported or pre‚Äëdelivered factors, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The difference is that the same setup now delivers additional impact categories and result views, so your existing data and methods serve a growing list of corporate and product requirements ‚Äì without extra integrations or parallel logic.

Footprint Results with additional Impact Categories

To learn more about this innovation, its business rationale, and how it supports your reporting requirements, check out my deep dive blog post: Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. It also includes a step-by-step walkthrough of the overall workflow and the enhanced apps. For complete documentation and technical details, visit SAP Help: Calculating Footprints for Different Impact Categories.

We will also publish additional blog posts in the SAP Community, explaining in detail how you can map the multi-impact calculation results to various reporting requirements. Stay tuned!

 

Streamlined Energy Management

Managing energy data for footprint calculations has often been repetitive and time-consuming. Previously, you had to enter the same energy data and meter readings multiple times for different calculation variants, making workflows cumbersome and prone to errors. This complexity increased further when handling periodic meter readings and energy bills across multiple locations.

With the latest release, we‚Äôve simplified this process significantly: For all newly created footprint calculations, energy bills and meter readings are now managed separately from the footprint inventory using two new types of GHG data forms. This means you can collect periodic energy data via the Record GHG Data app and reuse it across multiple calculations without redundant entries. Data maintenance is now independent of calculation variants, saving time and improving consistency.

We‚Äôve also introduced more flexibility: you can calculate energy-related footprints based on energy sources only, without the need for an energy flow model, which is a major advantage for Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) calculations. The user experience has been improved in the Calculate Footprints app as well, with data readings displayed directly on the first page of the inventory for quick access.

In the following, I‚Äôll briefly summarize the required process steps and what has changed in the existing apps. For the full documentation, see Maintain Energy Bills and Meter Readings Using GHG Data Forms on SAP Help.

To use the new approach, start by preparing your footprint inventory scope. In the Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes app, activate form-based data collection for energy bills and meter readings. If you plan to use meter readings in your energy flow model, make sure to include Direct Emissions and Energy Consumptions under Value Chain Steps. For energy bills, this step isn‚Äôt required.

Define Footprint Inventory Scope with Form-Based Data Collection

Next, configure your energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. When creating an energy source, choose Enter Energy Bills if you want to manage consumption through the Energy Bills form, or Use Meter Readings and Planned Consumptions for meter-based data. Meters themselves are created in the Manage Locations app and must be assigned to the relevant plants. If you include meters in your energy flow model, they need to be in place before creating the footprint inventory.

With the scope and energy sources ready, create GHG data collections for the relevant plants and periods in the Manage GHG Data Collections app. Then, record your periodic energy data in the Record GHG Data app. You can enter values directly in the UI. Alternatively, you can download the template for offline editing and mass upload, or you can use the enhanced API for automating data entry and connecting smart meters ‚Äì see the following chapter for details. Validation checks help ensure consistency, for example by flagging deviations greater than 30% from previous readings.

Record Meter Readings in GHG Data Form

Finally, run your calculation in the Calculate Footprints app. Newly created inventories no longer show separate tabs for energy bills and meter readings ‚Äì instead, these values are maintained in the GHG data forms, and the Data Readiness section provides an overview of form status and associated models.

Calculate Footprints: Data Readiness

 

Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections

Managing GHG data across multiple locations and form types can be a challenge, especially when dealing with large datasets. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre introducing a powerful new capability, allowing mass upload for GHG data forms. You can now upload different types of forms ‚Äì such as energy bills, meter readings, business activities, and waste data ‚Äì across locations using a single template in the Record GHG Data and Manage GHG Data Collections apps. The template includes tabs for each form type, making it easy to consolidate and manage data efficiently without repetitive manual entry. For all details, check SAP Help: Working with GHG Data Collections and Record GHG Data.

To take automation even further, the GHG Data Forms API has been enhanced with new endpoints and parameters for mass updates. This means you can retrieve and update forms programmatically, integrate with external systems, and even connect smart meters or IoT devices directly. Check out the API on SAP Business Accelerator Hub: GHG Data Forms.

These improvements reduce manual effort, increase accuracy, and save time. They‚Äôre also addressing several of the most requested features on SAP Influence.

 

Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements

High‚Äëquality emission factors are the backbone of accurate and audit‚Äëready footprint results. The broader and better your factor library, the fewer workarounds you need, the faster you can onboard, and the more confidently you can answer customer and regulatory requests. Last quarter, we‚Äôve expanded the default datasets, improved import templates and governance, and refined AI‚Äëassisted mapping ‚Äì so you can source, structure, and apply factors with less manual effort and higher precision.

With this release, the Manage Emission Factors app expands its default dataset substantially. We‚Äôve added two new source packages and refreshed an existing one to broaden coverage and improve alignment with logistics and fuel methodologies. Newly added are:

  • GLEC Framework (Smart Freight Centre): Harmonized logistics factors across road, rail, air, ocean/inland waterways, and parcel/last‚Äëmile; coverage for fuels and energy (TTW/WTT), logistics sites and equipment (warehousing, refrigeration, handling), plus rules for distance, allocation, and data quality aligned with ISO 14083.
  • German Environment Agency (Umweltbundesamt, UBA): Factors for fossil fuels including natural gas, hard coal, lignite, heating oils, diesel, gasoline, LPG, and more.

In addition, the UK DEFRA packages have been updated and now include the full set of emission factors. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data on SAP Help.

To make onboarding and governance smoother, and to align with the latest features, we‚Äôve updated the import templates in the Manage Emission Factors app. The simple template (v3) and the LCA template (v5) now support impact categories beyond Climate Change, including the selection of an LCIA method and its characterization factor per dataset ‚Äì so you can manage multi‚Äëimpact content consistently. In the Dataset Sources tab, you can add a source URL to the dataset for traceability, and unit validation has been tightened via the Dimensions column. We also streamlined context fields by adding a drop-down list to the Boundary column and moving it to the Emission Dataset tab to keep dataset‚Äëlevel semantics in one place. For all changes, visit SAP Help: Emission Factors Data.

With the Custom Datasets feature in the Manage Emission Factor app, you can assemble component datasets into a single, composite dataset to derive an overall emission factor when a product or activity‚Äôs direct factor is unknown ‚Äì leveraging known emissions of its parts to enable accurate footprint calculations. Now, those custom datasets also support multi-impact categories, so you can use it also for emission factors beyond climate change. For more information, see Creating Custom Datasets and Emission Factors on SAP Help.

Custom Dataset with Multi-Impact Emission Factors

We‚Äôve also refined the AI-assisted emission factor mapping in the Manage Purchased Product Footprints app. This powerful feature suggests mappings between products (or product groups) from your ERP system and emission factors from LCA databases. A new option, Show Enhanced Footprint Suggestions, is enabled by default and shifts similarity scores to prioritize commodity code first, then text similarity, then country/region. This enhances mapping precision where commodity codes are available. If your ERP master data or LCA packages lack commodity codes, you can switch the option off to revert to text‚Äëmatching. Exact matches are elevated when product names and dataset names align and commodity codes are consistent (or both absent), even if descriptions are missing. To reduce false negatives, AI no longer pre‚Äëfilters by unit convertibility and you‚Äôll only be blocked at release if unit conversions are missing in product master data. And for categories with sparse activity‚Äëbased data, AI now includes spend‚Äëbased factors when they rank among the top 10 suggestions. For all details, check SAP Help: Using AI to Map Emission Factors to Purchased Products and Product Groups.

Refined AI-assisted Emission Factor Mapping with Enhanced Footprint Suggestions

 

Other Release Highlights

To help you better understand your transport network at a glance, we added map visualizations for locations and transport routes across key apps. In the Manage Locations app, you can view locations on an interactive map along with details such as address, geocoordinates, postal code, and country or region. The Manage Transport Activities app now also provides a map-based view of generated routes and legs, helping you visualize transport flows more intuitively. On top of that, the Manage Transport Activities and Calculate Transport Footprints apps include an enhanced quick view for locations with an embedded map display. This means you can access location details and see them on a map instantly, streamlining your workflow and saving time.

Visualization of Transport Route and Legs

In my previous blog post, I introduced the Source Input Items feature in the Manage Footprint Results app that gives granular visibility into the inputs driving product emissions to identify hotspots and guide targeted decarbonization actions. We now enhanced this feature with the ability to generate source input items for cyclical calculations. This makes footprint analysis more comprehensive, especially for products calculated based on cyclical processes. On SAP Help, you find more information about source input items: Viewing the Footprint Results, and examples on cycle calculations: Calculating Cycles.

Another update improves data handling and coverage in the Import Business Transactions app: You can now add business transaction data to supplement imported records, with clear tracking of imported and added entries. New columns ‚Äì Imported Records, Added Records, and Entry Method ‚Äì provide transparency on how data enters the system, ensuring complete coverage for footprint calculations. The consolidated data (imported and added records) is then used to calculate footprints. For details, see Import Business Transactions, and for more information about business transactions' behavior, see Business Transactions Types on SAP Help.

Finally, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is now available in two additional regions: Europe (Frankfurt) and Brazil (S√£o Paulo), both on AWS. This expansion supports customers operating in these regions with improved availability and compliance.

 

Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide

To make it easier for you to adopt the latest capabilities, we‚Äôve expanded our enablement portfolio with new content and updates across multiple channels. Together with BearingPoint, we hosted a webinar that gives an overall introduction of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and also takes a closer look at multi-impact categories and what they mean for your sustainability strategy. Supported by a system demo, the session explains how these new dimensions help you move beyond carbon to a more holistic view of environmental performance. If you missed it, you can watch the full recording here:

We‚Äôve also updated the Learning Journey Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Advanced Configurations. A new unit now explains how to calculate GHG Scope 3.4 emissions using the ERP-centric transport footprint calculation capabilities introduced last year. This addition is particularly valuable for organizations looking to leverage existing ERP data for transport-related emissions without building parallel processes. It‚Äôs a practical guide to help you understand how these capabilities fit into your overall footprint model and reporting requirements.

In addition, we also published a new Scenario Guide that includes detailed process steps for calculating Scope 3.4 emissions based on data already available in your ERP systems: Process 8 ‚Äì Calculating Scope 3.4 Emissions Using Business Transaction Data.

These enablement updates are designed to make adoption easier and faster, so you can focus on turning sustainability data into actionable insights. Whether you prefer learning through webinars, structured journeys, or detailed guides, we‚Äôve got you covered.

 

BASF Coatings‚Äô Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

Recently, I joined the Inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud Podcast to discuss sustainability and share real-world examples of how our solutions create impact. A highlight was my conversation with Maximilian Bauer from BASF Coatings, who explained how they use SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to tackle the complexity of sustainability in their business.

BASF Coatings operates in a highly dynamic environment, producing thousands of product variations with every color shade counting as a new product. This creates massive data challenges when calculating footprints. With SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, BASF Coatings can now:

  • Scale and automate carbon footprint calculations for hundreds of thousands of products.
  • Integrate seamlessly into existing systems, embedding sustainability into daily operations.
  • Gain actionable insights to offer more sustainable products and make data-driven decisions.

As Maximilian Bauer said: ‚ÄúYou can only improve what you can measure ‚Äì and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management offers us exactly this.‚Äù

Looking ahead, BASF Coatings is moving beyond carbon to multi-impact footprints, covering categories like abiotic resource depletion to ensure responsible use of finite resources. They‚Äôre also scaling innovations such as biomass balance and ChemCycling¬Æ, replacing fossil-based raw materials with renewable or recycled alternatives. These steps position BASF to meet growing global demand for sustainable products and stay ahead of regulatory expectations.

BASF Coatings‚Äô journey illustrates why we‚Äôre evolving SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: from carbon-only to multi-impact sustainability footprints, enabling companies to manage risk, cost, and growth across multiple environmental dimensions ‚Äì all embedded in core business processes.

In the podcast, I also shared our broader vision: embedding sustainability into business processes, leveraging a single trusted data foundation, and using AI to make sustainability intelligent and scalable. By expanding beyond carbon toward multiple impact categories, we help businesses move from compliance to competitive advantage.

Listen to the full episode on Apple Podcast or Spotify.

entry.title: SAP ECC vs S/4HANA Integration Capabilities: A Practical Guide for Integration Architects
entry.content:
SAP System Exposure: The Complete Integration Capability Guide for ECC & S/4HANA

1. INTRODUCTION

When I'm asked to integrate an external system with SAP, the first question isn't "which tool should I use?" It's "what can SAP actually expose?"

After few years working across SAP ECC and S/4HANA landscapes with Integration Suite, I've learned that understanding what's available in your SAP system is just as critical as knowing how to integrate it. Yet most integration guides skip this foundation and jump straight to implementation.

This is the reference guide, it maps every integration capability available in SAP ECC and S/4HANA On-Premises systems, explains when to use each protocol, and provides the checklists you need to prepare your systems for Integration Suite connectivity.

What You'll Learn:

  • Complete inventory of integration capabilities in ECC vs. S/4HANA
  • RFC/BAPI, IDoc, OData, SOAP, and file interface fundamentals
  • Protocol comparison matrix with use case recommendations.
  • System preparation checklists for production readiness
  • Integration architecture patterns
  • Decision framework for choosing the right protocol.

Who This Is For:

  • Integration consultants working with SAP landscapes.
  • Solution architects designing SAP integrations.
  • Developers building connections to SAP systems.
  • Functional consultants exploring integration possibilities.
  • Anyone planning Integration Suite implementations.

Let's start with what SAP can actually give us.

 

2. SAP ECC INTEGRATION CAPABILITIES

SAP ECC has been the backbone of enterprise operations for decades. While it lacks some modern REST/OData capabilities, it provides robust, battle-tested integration interfaces that still power thousands of integrations today.

2.1 RFC (Remote Function Call) & BAPIs

RFC is SAP's proprietary protocol for synchronous communication between systems. BAPIs (Business Application Programming Interfaces) are standardized RFCs that provide access to SAP business objects and processes.

Key Characteristics:

  • Synchronous: Call and wait for response
  • Transactional: Can commit or rollback
  • Type-safe: Strongly typed parameters.
  • Widely available: Broad range of reusable standard BAPIs in ECC

Common BAPIs You'll Use:

BAPI Name

Purpose

Use Case

BAPI_PO_CREATE1

Create Purchase Order

External procurement systems posting POs

BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE

Post Goods Movement

Warehouse systems updating inventory

BAPI_MATERIAL_GETDETAIL

Get Material Master

E-commerce platforms fetching product data

BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST

Post Financial Document

External systems creating FI documents

BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2

Create Sales Order

CRM systems posting orders to SAP

BAPI_CUSTOMER_GETDETAIL

Get Customer Master

External apps accessing customer data

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction SE37 (Function Builder)
  • Discovery: Search pattern "BAPI_*"
  • Testing: SE37 ‚Üí Test/Execute
  • Authentication: RFC destination in SM59

When to Use RFCs/BAPIs:

Use When:

  • You need real-time, synchronous responses
  • Transaction integrity is critical (commit/rollback)
  • Complex business logic required
  • Creating or updating SAP documents
  • Reading data with complex selection criteria

Avoid When:

  • Processing large data volumes (use IDoc instead)
  • No immediate response needed (use IDoc/async)
  • Simple CRUD on standard entities (use OData in S/4HANA)
  • Performance is more important than transaction integrity.

 Integration Pattern:

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Purchase Order Creation from Web Portal

Business Context:
Manufacturing company has external procurement portal where buyers create purchase requests. Once approved, these need to become POs in SAP ECC instantly.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: Custom web portal (Node.js/React)
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • BAPI: BAPI_PO_CREATE1
  • Frequency: Real-time (on PR approval)
  • Volume: 50-100 POs per day

Process Flow:

2.2 IDoc (Intermediate Document)

IDoc (Intermediate Document) is SAP‚Äôs standard asynchronous integration mechanism.
It is designed for high-volume, reliable, loosely coupled data exchange between SAP and external systems.

An IDoc is:

  • Self-contained
  • Status-driven
  • Processed independently of user interaction

This makes IDocs ideal for batch integrations, master data replication, and guaranteed delivery scenarios.

Key Characteristics:

  • Asynchronous: Fire-and-forget or guaranteed delivery
  • Bulk-friendly: Efficient for large volumes
  • Loosely coupled: Systems don't need to be online simultaneously
  • Status-tracked: Built-in monitoring (WE02, WE05)

IDoc Structure:

Common IDoc Types:

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction WE30 (IDoc Type Development)
  • Partner Setup: WE20 (Partner Profiles)
  • Port Config: WE21 (Port Definition)
  • Testing: WE19 (Test Tool)
  • Monitoring: WE02 (IDoc Display), WE05 (IDoc List)
  • Triggering: Message Control, Change Pointers, IDOC_OUTPUT_* FMs

When to Use IDocs:

Use When:

  • High-volume data transfer (thousands of records)
  • Asynchronous processing acceptable
  • Standard SAP business documents (PO, Invoice, etc.)
  • Batch processing requirements.
  • Need for guaranteed delivery with retry.
  • Master data replication

Avoid When:

  • Real-time response required immediately
  • Complex transformations needed
  • Non-standard data structures
  • Simple CRUD operations (overkill)

Integration Patterns:

Outbound (ECC ‚Üí External):

Inbound (External ‚Üí ECC):

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Nightly Material Master Sync to Data Warehouse

Company needs to send all material master changes from ECC to external data warehouse every night for reporting and analytics.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: SAP ECC 6.0
  • Target: External Data Warehouse (Snowflake)
  • IDoc Type: MATMAS05
  • Frequency: Nightly batch (2 AM)
  • Volume: 5,000-10,000 materials per night

 End-to-End IDoc Asynchronous Integration Flow

  1. Material master records are created or updated in SAP ECC throughout the day (MM01/MM02).
  2. Change pointers capture only relevant delta changes for the MATMAS message type.
  3. At 2:00 AM, the BD21 batch job executes during off-peak hours.
  4. The system reads accumulated change pointers.
  5. A MATMAS05 IDoc is generated for each changed material.
  6. IDocs are sent via partner profile WAREHOUSE using an HTTP port.
  7. SAP CPI receives the IDoc XML through the IDoc adapter.
  8. CPI parses the hierarchical IDoc structure.
  9. Business data is transformed into a target JSON format.
  10. Records are grouped into batches of 1,000 for optimized processing.
  11. CPI posts each batch to the Snowflake bulk API.
  12. On success, IDocs are updated to status 53 (Posted).
  13. On failure, IDocs move to 51 (Error) and are retried in the next batch cycle.
  14. A consolidated processing report is emailed to the data team at 3:00 AM.

2.3 SOAP Web Services

SAP ECC exposes business functionality as SOAP-based web services using the Enterprise Services Repository (ESR).
These services are WSDL-driven, XML-based, and follow a strict request‚Äìresponse contract over HTTP/HTTPS.

SOAP services are widely used in legacy enterprise landscapes, especially where Java or .NET middleware already exists.

Key Characteristics:

  • Standards-based: WSDL, SOAP 1.1/1.2, WS-* standards
  • Synchronous: Request-response pattern
  • Platform-agnostic: Any SOAP client can consume
  • Structured: XSD-defined schemas

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction SOAMANAGER (Service Administration)
  • Development: SPROXY (Proxy Development)
  • Types:
    • Provider Services (ECC exposes to external)
    • Consumer Services (ECC consumes from external)

When to Use SOAP:

Use When:

  • External system requires SOAP/WSDL
  • Enterprise service repository already defined.
  • Need WS-Security features.
  • Cross-platform integration with Java/.NET systems

Avoid When:

  • Modern REST/JSON preferred (not natively supported in ECC)
  • Performance is critical (SOAP overhead)
  • Simple operations (BAPI or IDoc simpler)

Integration Pattern:

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Legacy Java Middleware Posting Financial Documents

Existing Java-based middleware system (10 years old) collects invoice data from multiple subsidiaries and needs to post consolidated financial documents to ECC.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: Java middleware (Spring Boot)
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • Service: FinancialDocumentCreate (Enterprise Service)
  • Frequency: Real-time as invoices arrive
  • Volume: 200-300 documents per day

Process Flow:

  1. Java app collects invoice from subsidiaries.
  2. Validates and enriches data.
  3. Builds SOAP XML per WSDL specification.
  4. Sends SOAP request to CPI endpoint.
  5. CPI routes to ECC SOAMANAGER
  6. Enterprise service validates structure.
  7. Calls backend BAPI for FI posting.
  8. Document posted, accounting entries created.
  9. Returns FI document number in SOAP response.
  10. Java app stores document number for reference.

2.4 File Interfaces

File interfaces are one of the oldest and most reliable integration mechanisms in SAP ECC, designed for scheduled, high-volume, non-real-time data exchange.
Data is exchanged using physical files that are picked up, processed, and archived in batch cycles.

This pattern is still widely used for:

  • Vendor uploads
  • Price lists
  • Mass master data changes
  • One-time or recurring migrations

File Formats:

  • Flat files (fixed width, delimited)
  • CSV/Excel
  • XML
  • Custom formats

Technical Approaches:

  • Output: Report programs, BDC, LSMW
  • Input: Batch Input (BDC), Direct Input, BAPI calls

When to Use Files:

Use When:

  • Batch processing windows.
  • Large data migrations
  • Legacy system integration
  • Offline scenarios

Avoid When:

  • Real-time requirements
  • Frequent small transactions
  • Complex error handling needs.

Example Scenario: Nightly Vendor Price Upload (CSV)

The procurement team receives daily price updates from multiple vendors.
Each vendor uploads a CSV file containing updated material prices, which must be reflected in SAP ECC before business hours.

Technical Setup

  • Source: Vendor SFTP servers
  • Integration Layer: SAP CPI
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • File Type: CSV
  • Schedule: Nightly (4:00 AM)
  • Volume: ~50 files, 10,000‚Äì15,000 records

Process Flow (Clear & Sequential)

  1. Vendors upload CSV price files to the SFTP server between 1:00‚Äì3:00 AM
  2. At 4:00 AM, SAP CPI scheduler triggers the batch job
  3. CPI connects to SFTP and downloads all available files
  4. For each file, CPI:
    • Identifies the vendor from the file name
    • Parses the CSV line by line
    • Validates mandatory fields and price values
  5. For each valid record:
    • CPI calls BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA
    • Updates the vendor price / info record
  6. Processing continues even if individual records fail
  7. CPI writes:
    • Success entries to the success log
    • Failed records to the error log with reason
  8. Processed files are archived to /archive
  9. A summary report is generated
  10. Email notification is sent to the procurement team

WHAT SAP ECC CANNOT DO (WITHOUT WORKAROUNDS)

ECC is powerful for traditional integration, but modern patterns require custom work. Understanding this shapes your architecture strategy.

NO NATIVE REST/ODATA APIS

ECC doesn't provide REST APIs out of the box. You can build them, but not easily:

Workaround Options:

  • NetWeaver Gateway add-on (SEGW)
  • ICF HTTP handlers (IF_HTTP_EXTENSION)
  • Custom ABAP REST wrappers
  • SOAP-to-REST via CPI

LIMITED EVENT-DRIVEN CAPABILITIES

ECC has event-like features, but not modern event streaming:

What You Get:

  • Change pointers (batch-oriented)
  • Workflow events (tightly coupled)
  • IDoc triggers (application-specific)

What You Don't Get:

  • Publish/subscribe architecture
  • Multiple independent subscribers
  • Event replay
  • True decoupling

Impact: Adding a new event consumer requires ECC configuration changes. Not cloud-native.

Why This Works:

  • ECC does what it's designed for: business logic.
  • CPI manages modern protocols, security, governance.
  • No custom code burden in ECC
  • Easy S/4HANA migration path

Strategic Guidance:

  • Use CPI for protocol translation.
  • Keep ECC focused on business processes.
  • Plan your S/4HANA path.

3. SAP S/4HANA ON-PREMISE INTEGRATION CAPABILITIES

S/4HANA builds on everything ECC provides and adds modern integration capabilities that change the game.

3.1 EVERYTHING ECC HAS, ENHANCED

RFCs/BAPIs:

  • All ECC BAPIs available
  • New S/4HANA-specific BAPIs
  • Better performance (HANA database)
  • CDS view consumption via RFCs

IDocs:

  • All ECC IDoc types
  • Improved processing speed
  • Better error handling
  • Enhanced monitoring

SOAP Services:

  • All enterprise services
  • Service adaptation framework
  • Better performance

3.2 ODATA SERVICES (THE GAME CHANGER)

OData is the REST-based protocol that makes SAP data accessible like modern APIs. This is what S/4HANA has that ECC doesn't, and it's transformative.OData introduces true RESTful APIs, designed for:

  • Web applications
  • Mobile apps
  • External developer consumption
  • Real-time queries

Why OData Matters

  • REST over HTTP
  • JSON-first
  • Queryable data access
  • Self-describing APIs

Key Characteristics:

  • RESTful: Standard HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE)
  • JSON/XML: Modern data formats
  • Query-capable: $filter, $select, $expand, $orderby, $top, $skip
  • Self-documenting: $metadata endpoint
  • Stateless: No session management needed

SAP Gateway Architecture:

 

Standard S/4HANA APIs (Examples):

API Service

Business Purpose

Key Entity Sets

API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV

Purchase Order lifecycle management

A_PurchaseOrder, A_PurchaseOrderItem

API_PRODUCT_SRV

A_Product, A_ProductDescription

API_SALES_ORDER_SRV

API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV

Technical Details:

  • Service Registration: /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE
  • Testing: /IWFND/GW_CLIENT
  • Development: SEGW (Gateway Service Builder)
  • Monitoring: /IWFND/ERROR_LOG

OData Query Capabilities

Basic Read

GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseOrder

Filtering

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder

?$filter=DocumentDate ge datetime'2025-01-01'

 and PurchaseOrderType eq 'NB'

Selecting Specific Fields

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder

?$select=PurchaseOrder,Supplier,DocumentDate,TotalAmount

Expanding Navigation Properties

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder('4500000001')

?$expand=to_PurchaseOrderItem

Pagination

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder?$top=100&$skip=0

Response:

"__next": "...&$skiptoken=100"

Metadata Discovery

GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV/$metadata

Returns:

  • Entity sets
  • Properties
  • Associations

When to Use OData

Use When

  • Modern web or mobile applications
  • Real-time queries required
  • REST/JSON integration
  • Flexible query support needed

Avoid When

  • SAP ECC system
  • Complex transactional rollback required.
  • Bulk data transfer

EXAMPLE SCENARIO: Mobile Sales App Querying Products

Business Context:

Sales representatives use mobile app to check product availability, pricing, and specifications while visiting customers. Need instant access to product catalog with real-time stock levels.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: React Native mobile app
  • Target: S/4HANA On-Premise
  • API: API_PRODUCT_SRV, API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV
  • Frequency: Real-time as sales rep searches
  • Volume: 500-1,000 queries per day

Process Flow:

  1. Sales rep searches "Bearing" in mobile app
  2. App sends HTTP GET to CPI endpoint
  3. CPI forwards to S/4HANA Gateway
  4. Gateway routes to Data Provider Class
  5. DPC queries HANA database (ultra-fast)
  6. Returns matching products as JSON
  7. For each product, fetch stock level
  8. Combine product + stock data
  9. Response returns to mobile app
  10. Rep sees list: 15 products with prices and stock

3.3 CDS Views as Integration Endpoints

Core Data Services (CDS) views are HANA-optimized semantic data models defined in S/4HANA. They represent business entities and logic at the database level and can be exposed directly for integration.

CDS views can be:

  • Exposed as OData services via SAP Gateway
  • Consumed internally or externally via RFC-enabled function modules

Key Benefits

  • High performance: Logic is pushed down to the HANA database
  • Pre-aggregated data: Reduces processing in the application layer
  • Embedded business logic: Calculations, annotations, and semantics included
  • Rich relationships: Associations allow navigation across related entities

Process Flow

CDS View ‚Üí Gateway Service ‚Üí OData ‚Üí Integration Suite

3.4 SAP Business Events & Real-Time Integration

S/4HANA introduces native event-driven integration capabilities, allowing systems to react immediately to business changes instead of relying on batch jobs or polling.

Key enhancements include:

  • Standardized business event triggers
  • Improved change detection
  • Workflow-driven event publishing
  • Native integration with SAP Event Mesh

Event-Driven Integration Pattern

S/4HANA Business Event ‚Üí Event Mesh Topic ‚Üí Multiple Subscribers (CPI iFlows) ‚Üí External Systems

Typical Use Cases

  • Purchase order approved ‚Üí Notify procurement portal
  • Stock level falls below threshold ‚Üí Trigger replenishment
  • Sales order created ‚Üí Update CRM system
  • Invoice posted ‚Üí Notify payment or reporting systems

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Real-Time Stock Alerts to E-Commerce

E-commerce website needs instant notifications when product stock falls below threshold to display "Low Stock" warnings and trigger replenishment.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: S/4HANA On-Premises
  • Targets: E-commerce website, Replenishment system, Analytics dashboard
  • Event: Material.StockChanged
  • Frequency: Real-time (as goods movements occur)
  • Volume: 2,000-3,000 events per day

Step-by-Step Flow

  1. Goods Issue Posted
    • A goods issue is posted in S/4HANA using transaction MIGO.
  2. Stock Update in HANA
    • The stock quantity is immediately updated in the HANA database.
  3. Business Event Triggered
    • The system triggers the business event Material.StockChanged.
  4. Event Published
    • The event is published to SAP Event Mesh.
    • Topic: inventory/changes
  5. Parallel Event Consumption
    • Multiple systems subscribe to the same event and process it independently.

Subscriber A ‚Äì E-Commerce System

  • Receives the event through a CPI iFlow
  • Updates the product page inventory
  • Displays a ‚ÄúLow Stock‚Äù indicator (e.g., ‚ÄúOnly 75 left‚Äù)

Subscriber B ‚Äì Replenishment System

  • Evaluates stock against reorder threshold (100 units)
  • If below threshold:
    • Creates a Purchase Requisition
    • Notifies the purchasing team

Subscriber C ‚Äì Analytics Dashboard

  • Updates real-time inventory charts
  • Stores event data in the data warehouse for reporting
  1. Independent Processing
    • Each subscriber processes the event independently and in parallel.
  2. Acknowledgement
    • Each system sends an acknowledgement back to Event Mesh.

 

Events are published once and delivered to multiple consumers in parallel, without tight coupling.

3.5 What S/4HANA Adds Over ECC

S/4HANA builds on the proven integration capabilities of ECC and introduces modern, API-driven and event-based features that significantly expand what is possible in real-time and cloud-native landscapes.

entry.title: Clean Core: Building a Flexible Custom Business Configuration for HTTP Endpoints in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction

This post presents a technique for creating configuration in SAP S/4HANA that fully respects clean‚Äëcore principles, while offering more flexibility than traditional ECC customizing (SM30 or SPRO).
The use case is particularly interesting because it also touches on best practices for connecting SAP S/4HANA to Integration Suite ‚Äî or more generally, to any public API.
However, the primary goal here is to explain how to build a Custom Business Configuration (CBC) ‚Äî the clean‚Äëcore replacement for SPRO entries ‚Äî and, more importantly, how to adapt it so that only selected fields are transport‚Äëcontrolled while others remain editable directly in each environment.
The result is a clean‚Äëcore‚Äëcompliant solution that is more powerful than legacy SPRO customizing.

Use Case

Connections from S/4HANA to external APIs are increasing significantly with SAP‚Äôs ‚ÄúAPI First‚Äù strategy. This is very true on my project: we call Integration Suite, which then calls public APIs while managing authentication and potential transformations.
On S/4HANA on‚Äëpremise or private cloud, the recommended practice is to use destinations (transaction SM59, type G for HTTP).
In public cloud, this would instead be done using Communication Arrangements.
A typical ABAP call looks like:
 
DATA(get_device_auth_destination) =
  cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_destination(
    i_name = 'DESTINATION_NAME' ).

DATA(http_client) =
  cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination(
    i_destination = get_device_auth_destination ).

http_client->get_http_request( )->set_uri_path(
  i_uri_path = '/path/endpoint' ).

DATA(http_response) =
  http_client->execute( i_method = if_web_http_client=>get ).

DATA(response_text) = http_response->get_text( ).
 In this simple example, both the destination and the endpoint path are hard‚Äëcoded.

The Problem

Good practice suggests that:
  • The API endpoint URL should not be stored in the program.
  • Ideally, there should be one dedicated destination per API, allowing:
    • API‚Äëlevel call authorization
    • Authentication configuration (e.g., principal propagation)
    • Timeout settings
    • Emergency deactivation of an API by disabling the destination
In practice, because most APIs go through Integration Suite, we want to avoid creating dozens of destinations.
We therefore use one common destination but still need the ability to override it when necessary.
To achieve this, we create a custom configuration, allowing us to define ‚Äî per flow type:
  • HTTP destination
  • Endpoint path
  • English description
  • Active / inactive flag
Here is the table:
 
@EndUserText.label : 'HTTP endpoint configuration'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #C
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zbct_a_httpendp {
  key client      : abap.clnt not null;
  key flow_id     : zhttp_endpoint_flow_id not null;
  rfc_destination : rfcdest;
  path            : zhttp_endpoint_path;
  is_active       : zhttp_endpoint_is_active;
  description     : zhttp_endpoint_description;
}
The requirement is:
  • Creating a flow ID with its initial settings must be possible only in the reference client.
  • But fields like path and active flag must be editable in all environments.

Creating the Custom Business Configuration

Once the table is created, generating a CBC object is straightforward:
open the ABAP Object Generator and select "Maintenance Object".
This automatically generates RAP objects (Restful ABAP Programming Model).
This is where it gets powerful: we can adjust these objects to control precisely which fields are editable depending on the environment.

Adjusting the Behavior Definition

Open the generated behavior definition (in my case ZBP_I_HTTPENDPOINTCONFIGU_S).
Our goal is:
  • The Edit button must always be enabled.
  • Some fields must be read‚Äëonly outside the reference client:
    • RFC Destination
    • Description
We simply define this logic in the behavior definition.
Next, open the implementation class (ZBP_‚Ä¶) and go to Local Types.
We remove the default "Edit" restrictions and implement our own logic to disable selected fields when the configuration is opened in a non‚Äëreference environment.
This ensures:
  • In production (or any non‚Äëreference client):
    ‚Üí only path and active flag are editable
  • In the reference client:
    ‚Üí everything is editable

Testing the Result

Open the Custom Business Configuration app and select your configuration object.
In a productive environment, you will see the expected restrictions: only the intended fields are editable.
In the reference client, all fields remain modifiable.

entry.title: New Events for Outbound Nota Fiscal
entry.content:
Hi everyone!  

Today, I would like to share with you some impactful insights directly from an SAP Note, which outlines a streamlined approach for sending the events listed in the NF-e Technical Note 2025.002 v1.30, published October 2025. 

You can implement these changes in the outbound invoicing option for Brazil by following the instructions on SAP Note‚ÄØ3692197 and SAP Note 3689265. 

Check out the latest updates and features in our What's New session on the SAP Help Portal: 

  • SAP S/4HANA:‚ÄØNew Events for Outbound Nota Fiscal 
  • SAP ERP:‚ÄØNew Events for Outbound Nota Fiscal 

The Process 

To send these events, you need to create a specific structure, as described in the "Manual da SEFAZ". You should create the new structure through the SEND_GENERIC_EVENT method from the CL_NFE_CLOUD_NFE_PROCESSOR class. This effectively sends the events using the IS_GENERIC_EVENT parameter, which is essential for declaring the structure. 

You have to name this structure as ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_XXXXXX. You replace the XXXXXX for the number of supported events from the NF-e Technical Note 2025.002 v1.30. For example: ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110.  

In this structure, you'll find control fields and event-specific fields that are mapped directly to the XML event. You have to build the DET_EVENTO structure, which can vary depending on the type of event. The field names differ between the backend system and their appearance in the cloud solution. Check the following example:  

The structure of the event 112110 (Informa√ß√£o de efetivo pagamento integral para liberar cr√©dito presumido do adquirente) is denoted as ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. This structure has the following string fields and their equivalent in the cloud solution, following the rules of name conversion: 

  • ATTR_VERSAO -> converted to a__versao to create the XML (you can check the rule to create XML attributes instead of elements in SAP Note 3692197) 
  • DESC_EVENTO -> descEvento 
  • C_ORGAO_AUTOR -> cOrgaoAutor 
  • TP_AUTOR -> tpAutor 
  • VER_APLIC -> verAplic 

Check the XML file obtained after the name conversion. To download the XML file, follow the steps mentioned in SAP Note‚ÄØ3692197.  

<detEvento versao="1"> 
   <descEvento>Informa√ß√£o de efetivo pagamento integral para liberar cr√©dito presumido do adquirente</descEvento> 
   <cOrgaoAutor>35</cOrgaoAutor> 
   <tpAutor>1</tpAutor> 
   <verAplic>1</verAplic> 
   <indQuitacao>1</indQuitacao> 
</detEvento>

DET_EVENTO Structure Declaration 

Create the structure‚ÄØ ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. Ensure the structure matches the following definition: 

TYPES: 
  BEGIN OF ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110, 
    a__versao        TYPE string, " XML Attribute 
    desc_evento      TYPE string, 
    c_orgao_autor    TYPE string, 
    tp_autor         TYPE string, 
    ver_aplic        TYPE string, 
    ind_quitacao     TYPE string, 
  END OF ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110.

Populating DET_EVENTO 

You populate‚ÄØthe DET_EVENTO‚ÄØ using assignment based on input parameters of the program. Check the following example: 

DATA : ls_event_112110 TYPE ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. 
ls_event_112110-a__versao = p_ver.         " Version - XML attribute 
ls_event_112110-desc_evento = p_desc.     " Event description 
ls_event_112110-c_orgao_autor = p_orgaut. " Author organization code 
ls_event_112110-tp_autor = p_tpaut.       " Type of authority 
ls_event_112110-ver_aplic = p_verapp.     " Application version 
ls_event_112110-ind_quitacao = p_indqui.  " Settlement indicator

Steps to Send a Generic Event 

Step 1: Declare and Populate IS_GENERIC_EVENT 

The IS_GENERIC_EVENT structure contains high-level control fields required for all types of events, including details such as issuing state, issuer's CNPJ, and access key (P_ACCKEY). Use the following template to populate the structure: 

DATA : ls_generic_event        TYPE nfe_cloud_nfe_map_gnrc_evt. 
ls_generic_event-uuid                = lo_uuid_generator->generate_uuid( ). " Unique identifier 
ls_generic_event-authorize_uuid      = p_authid.                           " Reference UUID 
ls_generic_event-issuing_state       = p_state.                           " State code 
ls_generic_event-environment_type    = 'HOMOLOGATION'.                    " Environment 
ls_generic_event-issuing_type        = 'NORMAL'.                          " Issuing type 
ls_generic_event-issuer_identifier   = p_issuer.                          " Issuer CNPJ 
ls_generic_event-receiver_identifier = '74544297000192'.                " Receiver CNPJ

Step 2: Declare and Populate Specific DET_EVENTO 

Based on the event type (P_TYPE), decide the specific structure for DET_EVENTO. For example: 

If P_TYPE = '112110', use the predefined structure ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110: 

DATA : ls_event_112110 TYPE ZNFE_MAP_EVENT_112110. 
ls_event_112110-a__versao = p_ver.         " Attributes mapped as XML attributes 
ls_event_112110-desc_evento = p_desc. 
ls_event_112110-c_orgao_autor = p_orgaut. 
ls_event_112110-tp_autor = p_tpaut. 
ls_event_112110-ver_aplic = p_verapp. 
ls_event_112110-ind_quitacao = p_indqui. 
ls_generic_event-event_info-det_evento->* = ls_event_112110.  " Assigning DET_EVENTO structure

Step 3: Send the Event 

Invoke the SEND_GENERIC_EVENT method:

TRY. 
  ls_result = lo_processor->send_generic_event( 
      is_generic_event       = ls_generic_event 
      is_company_definition  = ls_company_defition ). 
CATCH cx_nfe_cloud_invalid_value INTO lx_invalid_value. 
  lx_invalid_value->raise_message( ). 
  RETURN. 
ENDTRY.

Checking Event Status 

To verify the status of sent events, follow these steps: 

  1. Service Locator: Use CREATE_SERVICE_LOCATOR_OBJECT from the CL_J_1BNFE_CF_MONITOR class. 
  1. Service Type Parameter: Reference C_SERVICE_EVENT_STATUS from CL_J_1BNFE_CF_CONSTANT. 
  1. Map Events and Generate JSON: Utilize the STRUCTURE_SERIALIZATION method from CL_J_1BNFE_CF_EVENT_UPDATE. 
  1. Client and OA2C Creation: Use SET_REQUEST_JSON and SEND_REQUEST_TO_CLOUD methods from CL_J_1BNFE_CF_SERVICE_COMM. 
  1. Transform JSON Response: Apply GET_RESPONSE_FROM_CLOUD to convert the response into an NF-e format. 
  1. Develop Response Structure: EVENT_TABLE_DESERIALIZATION method helps integrate this into an NF-e structure. 

Building Your Application 

Beyond these steps, you'll need to develop or extend your applications to: 

  • Fill in necessary event data. 
  • Trigger creation and submission based on business processes. 
  • Implement error handling, logging, and monitoring according to your compliance standards. 

That's a wrap for today! I hope this guide serves as a handy reference for anyone navigating the intricacies of sending events in SAP. Stay tuned for more insights and happy coding! 

Until next time,

Nat√°lia

SAP e-Invoicing Application Engineer

entry.title: SBTi Forest, Land, and Agriculture (FLAG) in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
entry.content:
As companies work towards meeting their climate targets, the distinction between fossil and land-based emissions is becoming increasingly relevant. Emissions from forests, land, and agriculture (FLAG) follow fundamentally different dynamics than those from fossil fuels and materials. FLAG emissions have a significant share in global greenhouse gas emissions, play a critical role in climate mitigation, biodiversity protection, and food system resilience, which provides several advantages in environmental impact mitigation within value chains.

However, these emissions are often bundled together with Fossil GHG Emissions within corporate inventories without the level of detail to credibly manage them. This makes it difficult for companies to set realistic targets, assess progress, or transparently communicate the role of land-based emissions and removals within their GHG inventories. 

When properly understood as part of the natural carbon cycle, FLAG emissions become an important part of net-zero strategies: They are governed by biological processes that allows them to interact directly with removals and carbon storage within shorter timeframes compared to Fossil emissions. 

Against this backdrop, the latest updates to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management mark a significant evolution from a single-impact focus to a holistic environmental footprint analysis. The new capabilities expand impact coverage and explicitly distinguish between fossil and biogenic emissions and removals, enabling companies to reflect land-based dynamics more accurately. 

 Why distinguishing FLAG emissions matters at corporate and product level 

Distinguishing FLAG emissions from Fossil emissions is not just an accounting exercise. At the corporate level, separating FLAG from non-FLAG emissions allows companies to determine whether they are required to set dedicated FLAG targets under certain criteria and to incorporate mitigation pathways that reflect the realities of land-based systems.  

At the Corporate level, this differentiation enables a more realistic target setting, prevents the inappropriate use or double counting of removals within corporate inventories, supports transparent reporting, and progress toward emissions reductions. Without this separation, land use impacts can get hidden behind corporate totals, making progress appear stronger than it actually is.

Within a corporate level inventory, consistently separating FLAG emissions within Scope 3 improves transparency, avoids misleading pictures of progress, and enables more comparable and credible reporting across companies and sectors. To do this, a value chain perspective is needed to ensure all FLAG emissions are accounted across upstream and downstream activities, in order to avoid the risk of them being lost into broader corporate emissions totals, making it difficult to apply removals appropriately or to reflect the distinct mitigation dynamics of land-based systems. This approach is especially important given the limited and evolving guidance on corporate-level inventories for agriculture, forestry, and other land-use (AFOLU) activities.  

At the product level, the distinction becomes even more critical. For many products, particularly agricultural commodities, food, apparel, and bio-based materials, land use change and land management emissions dominate the product's carbon footprint. Without clear FLAG attribution, product claims can become misleading; comparisons across suppliers and materials lose validity, and the climate benefits of bio-based materials or regenerative practices may be obscured. Explicit identification of FLAG emissions  is therefore essential for credible product carbon footprints, meaningful supplier engagement, and alignment between product level claims and corporate transition strategies. 

 What is Science Based Targets initiative framework for Forest, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) 

The Science Based Targets initiative framework for Forest, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) guidance provides a dedicated framework for setting science-based targets that address emissions and removals from forests, land, and agriculture, alongside a company‚Äôs near-term and long-term climate targets. It clarifies which emissions fall within the FLAG boundary, how land-based emissions and removals should be accounted for, and how companies are expected to demonstrate progress over time in a way that reflects the biological and physical realities of land systems. 

Under the SBTi FLAG, companies are required to set a FLAG-specific target separate from other emissions targets when either of these conditions is met: 

  1. Sector-based requirement: Companies operating in SBTi-designated FLAG sectors, including forest and paper products, food production (animal source), food and beverage processing, food and staples retailing, and tobacco. 
  1. Emissions-threshold requirement: Companies in any sector whose FLAG-related emissions exceed 20% of total gross emissions across scopes 1, 2, and 3. This threshold must be assessed on a gross basis and cannot be netted against removals. 

When a FLAG target is required, companies must report emissions and removals across clearly defined categories that reflect distinct land-based processes: 

  • Land-use change emissions: Refers to CO2 released from carbon stock losses due to the conversion of land between land use categories, such as deforestation for cropland expansion. 
  • Land management emissions: Refers to both CO2 and non-CO2 gases arising from practices within the same land-use category, including tillage, cropping systems, livestock management, and rice cultivation. 
  • Carbon storage and removals: Refers to CO2 removed from the atmosphere through biological processes such as photosynthesis and stored in long-lived biogenic carbon pools such as forest biomass and soils. 

 To ensure transparency and comparability, companies setting FLAG targets are expected to provide disaggregated information that enables meaningful interpretation and review. This includes: 

  •  FLAG emissions and removals reported per commodity and per region 
  •  Separation of land-use change and land management emissions 
  •  Separate reporting of CO2 and non-CO2 emissions from land management activities 
  •  Removals reported by commodity, with further disaggregation across scope 1 and scope 3 categories encouraged 

 These reporting expectations align with the GHG Protocol Land Sector Guidance and the SBTi FLAG Annex submission requirements, supporting consistent and credible treatment of land-based emissions across corporate inventories. 

That‚Äôs where our new SBTi FLAG feature comes in. 

 SAP Sustainability Footprint Management for SBTi FLAG 

To facilitate detailed external reporting, especially frameworks like SBTi FLAG that require specific categorization of impacts, SAP's Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a powerful multi-impact category feature. This enables you to map calculated impact category results directly to relevant reporting categories, ensuring alignment with SBTi FLAG requirements. 

For this use case, the integration and calculation setup follow the same procedure as described in our "Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management" blog post. For SBTi FLAG, the process utilizes your ERP data to automate activity data collection, map to emission factors for the relevant impact categories, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The critical difference is ensuring that the relevant impact categories for FLAG are selected during the Footprint Inventory setup. 

Here, you'll define the boundaries and specific impact categories to be assessed in your environmental footprint calculation. This step is crucial for FLAG reporting and the following categories must be selected: 

  • Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management 
  • Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions 
  • Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals 

Additionally, Climate Change is always calculated as a mandatory impact category in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management; you can also choose to calculate additional categories, like abiotic resource depletion, in parallel with the FLAG analysis. 

For details, see Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes. 

You also need to ensure the inclusion of impact factors for the relevant categories using the Manage Emission Factors app. Each impact category requires a specific emission/impact factor. When populating either the LCA or Simple Template, input a separate entry for each category, even if they relate to the same product, energy source, or business activity, as they are distinguished by distinct Impact Category IDs. 

For SBTi, you must include the following categories are included via data packages: 

  • Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management (CCFL) 
  • Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions (CLCN) 
  • Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions (CLCLU) 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Emissions (CLCM) 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals (RELM) 

Climate Change (CLCH) impact factors must also be added, as this category is always mandatory in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Consuming apps like Manage Purchase Products Footprints, Model Energy Flows, Manage Waste Footprints, or Manage Business Activities will utilize these factors for relevant calculations. 

For detailed guidance on maintaining emission factors data, see Emission Factors Data. You'll find a table under Impact Categories, listing all categories, including their IDs, dimensions, and indicators. 

Aside from the impact categories being reported, other calculation parameters like master data, energy flow models, and periodic data remain unchanged. This ensures you can effortlessly scale calculations across different impact categories, allowing existing setups to smoothly adapt and include these additions 

For analyzing the calculated footprints, the Footprint Overview app offers a high-level summary of your impact calculation results, while the Corporate Balance app provides a consolidated view of your organization‚Äôs environmental performance. The Purchased Products analytics app now allows display of calculated footprints by impact category using a filter option. 

While the initial dashboards emphasize the Climate Change impact category, clicking on them allows for further detailed analysis. See Using the Footprint Overview Application for more information. 

The Corporate Balance app provides an overarching summary of your organization‚Äôs environmental performance. For more on viewing organizational emissions, see Using the Corporate Balance Application. 

The Purchased Products analytics app now provides a detailed understanding of the environmental burden associated with specific procured products across all selected impact categories, offering a richer perspective beyond CO2e. For more insights, see Using the Purchased Products Application. 

Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards 

The Impact Categories from Sustainability Footprint Management are designed to be standard-agnostic, serving as building blocks for supporting multiple reporting standards simultaneously. entry.title: A simplified approach to choosing between S/4HANA Public Cloud vs S/4HANA Private Cloud
entry.content:
One of the fundamental decisions that organisations are facing as they plan their transition to Cloud ERP, is the deployment option to choose. In SAP terms the question becomes: Would S/4HANA Public Cloud or S/4HANA Private Cloud be the better choice?

At high level, S/4HANA Public Cloud is a "ready-to-run" solution prioritizing standardization and deployment speed, while S/4HANA Private Cloud is a "tailored-to-fit" solution enabling flexibility and customization. In reality, the selection between the two is more complex with different parameters to consider. This article aims to ease the decision process through a simplified approach.

The right deployment option could, and most often should, be subject to a series of workshops and careful assessment of an organisation's specific needs. Still, experience from customer engagements has enabled me to develop a simplified approach which helps provide initial steering.

Overall, where possible, S/4HANA Public Cloud should be the ultimate destination. This due to its unique qualities, including faster access to innovation, a simpler Cloud operating model and reduced Total Cost of Ownership (TCO). On the flip side, Public Cloud also comes with limitations as compared to S/4HANA Private Cloud. These include a narrower implementation scope, reduced system control and the need to leave customisations and certain data behind.

To simplify the decision, as a rule of thumb an organisation should opt for S/4HANA Public Cloud if the following three elements match their needs:

  • S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation scope. Public Cloud offers  broad functionality covering the needs of most organizations and is becoming constantly richer in scope. Still, some functionality such as industry-specific scenarios may be unique to Private Cloud. The way to confirm that Public Cloud vs Private Cloud is fit for purpose is by completing the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment in collaboration with SAP or your Partner.
  • New implementation as migration option. A migration to Public Cloud can be completed only via a new implementation, while a migration to Private Cloud can also be completed via a system conversion or Selective Data transition for organisations on a legacy SAP ERP system. If you are new to SAP, then a new implementation is your clear way forward. If you are moving from a legacy SAP ERP system though, then it is key to validate that a new implementation is right for you. A new implementation requires that custom code and custom processes from your legacy SAP ERP system are left behind - which could actually be an opportunity for moving to a Clean Core and reinventing business processes using SAP's Best Practices. A new implementation also requires that previous transactional data aka closed items are left behind e.g. archived, otherwise maintained in the legacy ERP system (online as read-only or offline as a backup/image). Unless there is a specific need to bring closed items to the new Cloud ERP environment, leaving these behind helps run a lighter, easier to maintain and more cost-efficient system.
  • Public Cloud Operating model. Public Cloud is equivalent to SaaS, as opposed to Private Cloud which is similar to IaaS/PaaS. This means that Public Cloud is highly standardised, enabling rapid innovation at a lower TCO, offering a Clean Core and SAP‚Äëcontrolled operations and allowing the customer to focus on what matters to them most. It comes with Application Management Services included, therefore, among others, SAP is taking care of  application management including release updates and Middleware. Still, in Public Cloud, extensibility options are limited (classic ABAP extensibility not possible), the customer has no control over release upgrades (these are mandatory without the option to postpone and with a time-restricted regression testing window), and has no control over infrastructure choices either (no Hyperscaler selection). If the organisation has a particular requirement for any of these or for an overall operating model of shared responsibility with SAP, then Private Cloud might be better suited.

    While the above three elements focus mostly on the technical aspects of the deployment option decision, it comes without saying that the company's culture is also a major decisive factor. The appetite to reimagine processes and outsource a large part of IT operations to the software vendor while re-focusing on innovation activities, are of paramount importance for a Public Cloud deployment.

    All that said, the value and fit of Private Cloud for certain organisations should not be overlooked. Many enterprises, especially those with regulatory constraints, multi‚Äëlayered integrations, high customisation, heavy data volumes, or deep industry-specific implementation scope, continue to find Private Cloud more practical and in cases the only suitable option.

    To summarise, if you are an organisation planning a transition to SAP‚Äôs Cloud ERP and considering your deployment option, your actionable next steps are as follows: complete the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment to confirm whether the scope of S/4HANA Public Cloud matches your functionality needs, evaluate whether a new implementation vs system conversion is fit for purpose, and assess whether the Public Cloud operating model suits you. If the answer to all three questions is yes, and you establish the right company culture, then lead with S/4HANA Public Cloud. Otherwise, in case of unique requirements and a more complex landscape, S/4HANA Private Cloud might be a better fit. 

    Disclaimer: The approach suggested in this article reflects my views based on experience from working with different organizations, rather than SAP's official views. It aims to provide simplified guidelines and initial steering, but does not replace the need for more thorough assessment.
